Minor code-style thing: the rest of the file doesn't generally use braces in variable expansions (unless required for some non-default expansion like `${foo#xyz}` or something); it's be nice to stay consistent with that IMO.

It depends where one looks:

```
# Move the secondary GPT to the end of the device if needed. Look for the GPT
# header signature "EFI PART" located 512 bytes from the end of the device.
if ! tail -c 512 "${mmcdev}" | hexdump -C -n 8 | grep -q "EFI PART"; then
    sgdisk -e "${mmcdev}"
    partprobe
fi
```

But I won't insist on this style.
Done
Why not just use the (much more readable) hex notation instead of putting it in a comment?
I had used $((0x80000002)) but the shell that's being used at this point converts this into a negative number and then nothing works.

Ah...forgot that the initramfs shell is busybox instead of the usual bash (which apparently uses 64-bit ints for arithmetic variables even on 32-bit platforms).  Experimenting a bit though, it looks like the busybox shell's `printf` will interpret and print the hex in unsigned form though, so maybe `evm_act=$(printf %d 0x80000002)` instead?

...

Except wait -- why do we even need it in decimal form to begin with?  The kernel will usually interpret hex prefixes written to its various magic files (and from a quick glance at `security/integrity/evm/evm_secfs.c` I don't see any reason it wouldn't in this case, since it's just calling `kstrtouint_from_user()`), so I'm pretty sure it should be fine to just do

```
evm_act=0x80000002
```

(and then remove the duplicate `0x` prefix from the printf message.)
Yes, not having the shell convert the hex number is the solution. Next time i push it will be fixed.
Done

Might we want an `else` here with an error message for the failure case?  I imagine `echo` will print some minimal thing of its own, but it'd probably fairly cryptic (e.g. just "echo: invalid argument" or similar).
Ack

I don't know how widespread a practice it is, but as a small stylistic thing for boolean shell variables personally I prefer using `true` and `false` as the actual values -- you can then test them by just doing `if $variable; then ... `.
Done
This will result in the message printing `0x0x80000002` (duplicate `0x` prefix); the one in the format string should now be removed.
Or actually I suppose it won't, nevermind.  (I guess it would in the case of `%s` or `%#x`, but not with a plain `%x`.)

In the context of the init script I suppose it's unlikely to matter in practice since both stdout and stderr will be pointing to the same place (the system console), but as a matter of general principle I'd suggest adding `>&2` here.

Also, I'm totally unfamiliar with the mechanics of the components involved here, but if EVM activation fails does it still make sense to continue on with the rest of the function, or should we have a `return 1` or something here as well?  (And I guess correspondingly, is there anything the call site at line 466 can or should do on failure?)

None of the other echo's in this file printing out an error statement redirects to stderr `>&2`. I would create an inconsistency in this case. Examples:
```
echo "Fatal error, triggering kernel panic!"
 echo /bin/sh failed, retrying
 echo "Download failed."
```

If EVM initialization was to fail, and the reason for this should only be a broken kernel since I am testing for availability of `/sys/kernel/security/evm`, then IMA could still be activated and do IMA signature verification.
Fair enough, that sounds reasonable then.
As mentioned I don't really know anything about IMA & EVM, but it looks OK to me script-wise, so +1.

Does this mean that everyone must enable IMA or this script will halt boot? Or do we continue to boot regardless of whether IMA setup succeeds? Or have you ensured that `no_ima` is the default for every platform using the static NOR layout?

Some more comments to cover those points would be helpful.

The no_ima verb in the $optfile was meant to disable IMA during development if it was otherwise enabled. I can remove this if it is found not to be useful.

OpenBMC will work without IMA and EVM activated as before. The configuration file conf/local.conf has to be adjusted by the developer to enable them. This function here will not interfere with systems that don't have these built in. 

If securityfs is missing, it will return immediately. If the EVM key is missing, it will not activate EVM. If the IMA policy is missing, it will not activate IMA. If keyrings are not supported or don't accept the keys on the .ima or .evm keyrings, it will not activate either EVM or IMA. The additional kernel compile-time options and files (keys, IMA policy) are enable via options that are by default commented in conf/local.conf.
Ack

no_ima is considerably shorter than the other options used by this script.  However, those were chosen to avoid collisions with other users of the kernel command line.  Also, since we use grep without confirming spaces before or after, its important to make sure that strings can not be found as a substring of some other option.

If no_ima is used by some other distro or init script system, I'm fine adopting it.  However, if this was just created for this script, I'd prefer something else.

Also, at other points we test the $optfile before other tests.

It was just created for this script.

It's really unfortunate someone decided "/root" was good place to mount the future-rootfs.  As I'm reading through all of the changes you made referencing /root my primary thought is "why are we doing things in root's home directory?".

There are several variables representing paths, and the assembly path can be moved in a separate patch.

There are other root mounting sequences that use /root for the assembly point, and when I learned UNIX root used /.
